) IRC

provides a transferee liability against a recipient (transferee) of property from the transferor, for the tax liability of the transferor and is a to Working used to collect a taxpayer’s tax liability. A transferor is the person or entity in who created the tax liability and transferred assets to another party. The feree is the person or entity who is additionally liable for the tax (because received the transferred assets for less than full, fair and adequate ation). (

) The government can assess another taxpayer’s (transferor’s) liability transferee to collect this tax liability based on some other provision of state federal law. The liabilities include taxes, penalties and interest. Taxes and penalties are computed through the date of the transfer, while interest may be limited to the date of the transfer. It also includes additional liabilities resulting from an examination. (

) Appeals considers and processes transferee cases in much the same as other cases. The administrative file of a transferee case must contain tax returns of the transferor with a revenue agent’s report. (
) Use current transcripts to confirm the liability was assessed against either transferor or one or more transferees. (
) Refer to IRM
, Verification of New Information, for procedures regarding the verification of new information or evidence received during appeals process. (

) When establishing transferee/transferor cases on CASES, remember the following: and a. The transferor is the key case in the work unit, with each transferee Support established as a related return. b. The total tax (deficiency) dollars are shown by tax period on the or’s case with no duplication shown. c. When there are multiple transferors in a case, each transferor and related transferees are established as a separate work unit. This helps when researching specific cases. d. When showing the liability per tax period for each transferee case, remember to show the same amount in duplication. e. When establishing transferee/transferor cases, use Non-Master File codes in certain data elements to distinguish the case from Master (MF) cases with the same name that might be in the office at the time. The codes also help when researching or updating specific based on work unit number, TIN, and MFT. (

) Unlimited liability cases: Value of the assets the transferee receives from the transferor exceeds the transferor’s unpaid tax liability, or deficiency. The of the transferee is the full amount of the unpaid tax or deficiency of the transf- eror. (
) Limited liability case: Value of the assets transferred to the transferee is less than the transferor’s unpaid tax liability, or deficiency.
Limited liability case: Value of the assets transferred to the transferee is less than the transferor’s unpaid tax liability, or deficiency.

) If the transferor made payments to reduce the liability, the payments are against the tax, penalties and interest for the earliest tax periods first. a. The net remaining unpaid liability is reflected on the settlement tion. (

) Since notices of deficiency are not issued to a taxpayer for excise taxes, no notice of transferee liability is issued to a transferee regarding excise taxes. (

) The following provides a simple overview of limited and full liability: a. Limited Liability - Generally, the liability of the transferee is limited to the excess of the value of the assets received from the transferor over the consideration paid by the transferee for the assets, if that excess is less than the unpaid liability of the transferor. If more than one year is in a limited liability situation, state the transferee liability as one figure in the notice and do not allocate the transferee liability to various years. b. Full Liability - Generally, where the excess of the value of the assets received from the transferor over the consideration paid by the for the assets is more than the unpaid liability or deficiency of the eror, the transferee is liable for the full amount of the unpaid liability or deficiency of the transferor. If more than one year is involved in a full liability situation, assert the transferee liability for the same years as of the transferor. (

The enclosed statement shows how we figured the transferor’s deficiency.” b.
